div.p:
I have now before me
a most kind and delightful letter of yours
dated October 16, 1836!!

I am shocked at the thought of its
having remained above a year unanswered
unacknowledge - How ungrateful you have
had cause to think me and how wanting
not only in good feeling but in common good
manners. Believe me my dear Madame
that I am not to blame though appearances
are so much against me. The fact is that
both your letter and dear Louisa's remained
in one of the books which Mr. Norton sent to
London for me. The books have remained in
London ever since and my brother Francis who lately
opened one of the volumes there found the
two letters and sent them by post to me -

- I have but just received them and I hasten
to thank you with all my heart. Your letter
not only flattered me in the highest degree
by your approbation of my writings but
delighted my heart with the idea that
they had been of use and pleasure to you
and to your family, and that they had called
in your affectionate mind such benevolent
partiality for me - I feel very much obliged
to Mrs. Ticknor for having kept alive these
kind dispositions by her account of her vi-
sit visit to our home, I wish you could come and
judge for yourself - I feel almost sure that there
are some in this family you would love &
esteem, and in the happiness of seeing that
belief confirmed I should I trust be satisfied
though you might be disappointed in in my little
self - Mr. and Mrs. Ticknor have set you the
example and shewn you the possibility of
g coming to the middle of Ireland and in spite
of our said disturbances of being safe in Ireland
- The savage virtue of hospitality in trouble is not
yet gone from us - I wish you and Mr. Dearborn
would seriously think of it and bring your Louisa
to us and arrange so as to make us a decently
long visit and not such a tantalizing short vis as
those most agreeable Ticknors made us - They have
promised to come again before they return to their
own world - Suppose you were all to arrange to meet
at Edgeworthtown - Why not? -

If I understand rightly the books which
Mr. Norton sent me and in which your two
letters were found were a set of an American
Edition of my Tales & novels in 18 or vols. - which were
sent to me, as a present from Mr. Ticknor - I am not
sure where Mr. Ticknor is at this moment or I would
write to thank him. As I have one copy of Har-
purs Edn. Edition of those books in 18 vols. bound in 9 - sent
to me by the booksellers themselves, I have allow
ed allowed the set which Mr. Ticknor sent me to remain
in the hands of my brother Francis and his wife
who reside near London, and who had not those
books in any forms and they are charmed with
this beautiful American Edition - The paper is very
good and the printing & it is well corrected and
the American engravings are excellent - The
Vignette in the last volume of Helen, the hawking
scene is much the prettiest I have seen - There are
no embellishments for Helen in either the London
or French editions - I am very proud of her having found
such favor in America

I have been unpardonable if I have never
written to thank you for the Translation you sent me
of "my prisons" - I have long had it and have it at
this moment before me with the inscription in the
front page written with your own kind hand
and signed C E Norton - I cannot believe that I never
wrote about it - I do think some letter of mine has
been lost - But I will not assert it as I am not
sure - Of this I am sure that I like your translation
very much - It reads quite like an original
- We never had it in English before and yours
came and we could only translate bits of it
to my Aunt Mary Sneyd - an old lady who enjoyed
it particularly - From your translation she
heard it afterwards in perfection, and now
she wishes to hear it again and we will begin
to read it to her again the moment we have fi :.
-nished finished a very disagreeable (though clever) novel
which we are now reading - And to which it is
in every way & especially in the mild benevolent
feelings it excites the greatest contrast imaginable

- The novel we are reading is Mrs. Trollope' Vicar
of Wrexhill - It would lead me too far & perhaps,
weary you to enter into any criticism of it - But
I wish Mr. Norton would write a review of it for
Your excellent American Review - It is a subject
worthy of him - & he would treat it so well -
- It is not fair in fiction to draw a hypocrite or
heinously bad character as the representative of
certain religious tenets - a desperation & also grace
I do not at all agree with the evangelical or Calvinestic
tenets but I do not think this The way to refute them

If one should Mrs. Trollope had said "See the comparison
of separating faith & good works" - that would have
been a fair subject for exemplifying - but this Vicar is only
and Sir Walters friendship for us

But there is one letter of Sir Walters to me which
I must regret both for my sake and his own that
he has published and as I have written to say so to
himself honestly, as a friend should, I now tell it with
the less scruple to you - It is the letter in which he
Sir Walter
not only mentions Mrs. Grant of Edn. Edition in a way which I
am certain he could not mean to publish - but also in which
he mentions an American correspondent of mine -
(happily not named) But still so described that all who know
her must find her out - Also in which Sir Walter wrote
writes to me confidentially of the Americans in general
- a "funny people" - wanting cushions to their benches" &c -

I reproach myself very much for having let
this letter go with the rest to Lockhart - I had never
Shewn it - even to Mr. Ticknor who when he was here
I had treated with a sight of Sir W's, other letters - I had
not the least idea that Lockhart would have published
it - And I am very sure now even that it is published,
that it was by mistake, & in consequences of his mind's
being so overwhelmed as it was by the sudden death
of his own Sophia that dear wife upon whom he
douted & well he might! - Mrs. Lockhart was the
person who had as long as she lived looked over the
letters & life with him & copied I know all the letters
papers from the letters for publication - her death
came upon him just as he had published the 4th vol
and there was a stop in the publication for 2 or 3 months
- I imagine that Lockhart was unable thimself to look
over all the papers for the 5th. volume carefully &
that he only wrote papers & let others of his friends
select select letters - & only cursorily gave a look at them & in this
the letter Lollard ??? overlooked
only a horrid hypocrite - And his faults
Spring from his selfishness, profligacy, love
of power, and hypocrisy but not from the Reli
gious Religious peculiar touch he holds - at least as far as
the author of the fiction Shews. The falsehood or
truth - the pernicious or beneficial effect of those
tenets remain untouched apon ; just as much as
the Catholic doctrines are untouched by Moliere's
Tartuffe - It is hypocrisy only that is unmasked & chastised

If the author means to charge upon the Evange-
-lical Evangelical sect the underhand pernicious immoral practices so
ascribed to her Tartuffe and his set; & without ascribing
them to the peculiar tenets to assert that these are
the general practices & habits of that sect, Then
the question remains as a matter of fact - whether
this be true or not? - That is a question which a
novel cannot possibly decide, in as much as it is not
true itself in general nor even an example of a particular fact or
choices of facts - But it may waken public attention to
the examination into the facts - And it may also
waken individuals who are of this sect and who are
not hypocrites to reflexion upon the consequences
of the language (cant) and manners they have adopt-
-ed adopted from imitation perhaps, without having been
aware of their bad effects or without having been
made sensible of their absurdity - this is a service
which Ridicule sometimes does for Truth - In the Bazaar
drinking scene - it is well done - (If had not
been done by a woman - that disgusts and counter
acts the effect upon the mind of the reader) -

In The horrid Corbold sleeping room scene - is quite
on the contrary is only an unmasking of a brutal
hypocrite - His pretending to be Evangelical is nothing
to the purpose - he is diabolical - and whatever
tenets he professed they should not be charged -
with his (I hope) unnatural character - If it be
meant that there are many such among the Evangelicals
& more than among other sects, this again is a
question of matter of fact - to be decided by inquiry
- also it shd be inquired whether independantly of any thesis, otherwise we
there is by the evangelical sect a fanatical species round the young minds and
domestic happiness their unfuered and the
ties of
nature
& the
affections
& duties
of children
to parents
overturned
and
destroyed
These
are all
to be in
agreement
into as
matters
either
of
fact
or
not
of fact -

I must stop - for I am saying too much
and too little - It is a subject that ought not
to be touched unless it be examined to the bottom
& fully discussed - and that cannot be done in
a letter - nor by a woman - because however
able or well informed, (as in Mrs. T 's is the case) she
cannot go into the business without throwing off
the delicacy modesty & reserve of her sex; and tho
she may say Truth is of no sex - yet human nature
& man's nature and public opinion is are disgusted
in the outset, and cannot listen calmly or unprejudiced
to such an unveiled p prophetess - or
naked female pleader -

The hand that is fit for this business must be strong but not coarse
- resolute but not rash - My respects to Mr. Norton I wish he or
Channing would take it in hand - We want to know what is thought of
this book in America or at Boston -

I am sure that in writing to you my dear
Madam I need not caution you against publishing
anything I write in confidence - I am sure
that from the delicacy of your own mind as
expressed in your letters you feel upon this
subject as I do, that it is a breach of confidence
to make known in any way private letters
without the authors especial leave

And this leads me though I have already
made this letter unconscionably long to add a
few words about a Work in which you will
see some letters published not of mine but addressed to me -
- I mean in Lockharts life of Sir Walter Scott - Sir
Walter to me - At first I had refused to give up
any of his letters for publication upon the general
principle that I have stated above - But considering that
Lockhart who had been empowered by Sir W. to publish
What he pleased must know his wishes upon the subject
I did send my whole portfolio full of Sir Walter Scotts
letters to Lockhart charging him to be very careful in
the selection for the public - And as far as relates to his
first business as a biographer I think he had s accomplished it
admirably by means of Sir Walters own letters by making
him as much as possible his own biographer - And I am not
not only well pleased but highly gratified by all he has
published in Sir W's letter to Joanna Baillie & myself respecting me & my family (especially our dear lost sister
Sophie ) - This is done with great delicacy particularly
Where Lockhart writes of his own Sophia & in his own person of
her
- and a few a very few other passages I cd
wish omitted - But I hope you will
agree with me, in liking upon the whole
this interesting work, and in thinking it
a noble monument to Sir Walter Scotts benevo-
-lent benevolent & moral character, as well as to his astonish
-ing astonishing unparalled literary genius & industry

I tremble for the 2 vol! that are to come
Two Lockhart writes me word there must be
though he had proposed to finish with the 6th
- there must be a seventh to complete his task

He has to tell of the sad reverse in Scotts
worldly affairs - And this & all his money &
bookselling or manuscript selling transactions he
must enter into even at the hazard of being
tedious; because these are all matters which ???
Scotch public, and the Ballantynes & Constable
Set require should be laid before the public -
They have trusted Lockhart with their papers upon
The faith is that he shd do this - And as Sir Walters
friend & biographer he feels bound to do it; for
if he did not (as he writes to me) they would and
he can do it better than any body else

He says he longs to get over these details
and to get to the pa ? rt where the great catastrophe his
ruin of fortune comes - because then he has to
represent a great man struggling with adversity
a spectacle worthy of the God's & of All good men
of all who in the civilized & moral world will I
Think have their sympathesing hearts in this case
fixed upon this man of genius who absolutely
sacrificed his genius, his life, his intellects
to his sense of honor & honesty - his moral sense

You in your new world are more likely than we here to see & feel this
impartially -
div.closer:
Adieu my dear Mrs. Norton - forgive
my too much and believe me very sincerely
and affectionately your obliged
Maria Edgeworth

me, if you are so kind to write please to put your
letters in one cover & direct them only on the sealed side
there - To Miss Edgeworth Edgeworthtown Ireland -
Then put your packet thus directed into another cover and
direct that To the Clerk of the Council in waiting
Council Office
London

any letter or even pamphlet
pamphlet - but no bound books must be put into
